config.topic: What happened to research on automated visualization?
config.target_audience: researchers in the visualization community, they might be interested in both topic evolution and how people in the field shape the research (such as their interactions and key players)
config.domain_knowledge:
Regarding identification of automated visualization papers:

The following keywords are used to identify the automated visualization papers:
- automatic vis
- automated vis
- visualization recommendation
- mixed initiative
- mixed-initiative
- visualization generation
- vis generation
- agent

An example vega-lite filter:
test(/automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent/i, (datum.AuthorKeywords || '') + ' ' + (datum.Abstract || '') + ' ' + (datum.Title || '')) ? 'AutoVis' : 'Other'

report_outline.section_description: Succinct overview of the key findings about automated-visualization (AutoVis) research: whether it grew, stabilized, or declined; who led it; and the main thematic shifts. Frame specific research questions the report answers.

content.text: Automated-visualization (AutoVis) is a small but increasingly visible strand inside Vis publications: it represents a few percent of the corpus overall, has clear leadership from a handful of influential systems and research groups, and has shifted from early system- and rendering-focused work toward recommendation, model-driven design, and user-centered evaluation. This report answers three focused questions: (1) How has AutoVis changed in volume and share of Vis publications over time — did it grow, plateau, or decline? (2) What themes, methods, and topics characterize AutoVis work and how have they shifted? (3) Who are the key people and institutions shaping the area, and what are the field-level gaps (e.g., reproducibility, evaluation, deployment) that warrant attention? In short: AutoVis began as a niche activity, accelerated after the mid-2010s with notable system contributions (Voyager, Draco), peaked in absolute and relative counts around 2021, and is now more thematically diverse — combining recommender-style systems, mixed-initiative interfaces, and stronger emphasis on empirical evaluation — but still shows important gaps in reproducibility and long-term impact tracking.

report_outline.section_description: Describe the Vis publication dataset (attributes available) and operational definition of ‘automated visualization’ used in the study. Specify the keyword-based filter (automatic vis | automated vis | visualization recommendation | mixed initiative | mixed-initiative | visualization generation | vis generation | agent) and how Title / Abstract / AuthorKeywords are combined and preprocessed.

content.text: The analysis uses a curated Vis publication dataset of 3,877 records with roughly 20 attributes per record (Conference, Year, Title, DOI, Link, PaperType, Abstract, AuthorNames, AuthorNames-Deduped, AuthorAffiliation, InternalReferences, AuthorKeywords, AminerCitationCount, CitationCount_CrossRef, PubsCited_CrossRef, Downloads_Xplore, Award, GraphicsReplicabilityStamp, and page information). For the study we operationalize “automated visualization” with a keyword-based filter applied to Title, Abstract, and AuthorKeywords. The filter looks for terms and phrases that explicitly evoke automation, recommendation, mixed initiative, generation, or agents (regular expression terms: automatic vis | automated vis | visualization recommendation | mixed initiative | mixed-initiative | visualization generation | vis generation | agent). Text fields are lowercased, non-alphanumeric characters are normalized to spaces, and Title/Abstract/AuthorKeywords are concatenated when identifying matches; AuthorKeywords are also exploded and normalized for keyword-level analyses. This approach favors high precision for explicit AutoVis terminology while recognizing it misses work that engages automation implicitly without the target keywords.

content.text: The completeness visualization summarizes how well each attribute in the Vis dataset is populated. Conference, Year, Title, DOI, Link, and PaperType are fully complete (100%), and most bibliometric fields such as CrossRef citation counts and raw AuthorNames are nearly complete (~99.9%). Abstract text is available for almost all records (98.2%) and contributes the largest body of characters overall — on average ~1,130 characters per non-missing abstract — which makes the corpus rich for textual analysis. In contrast, meta-metadata that supports reproducibility or awards is sparse: GraphicsReplicabilityStamp appears for only 27 records (0.7%) and Award is present for about 7% of records. These gaps imply that while content and bibliometrics are well-covered for topic and citation analyses, reproducibility and impact indicators will need careful handling and perhaps external augmentation.

content.text: The AutoVis-identification visualization reports how many papers the keyword filter flagged, which fields carried the matching keywords, and gives examples. Across 3,877 Vis papers the filter identified 83 AutoVis papers (about 2.1%). Matches come predominantly from abstracts (56 papers) and author keywords (42 papers); only 16 papers had the keywords in titles. The most common single-field pattern was Abstract-only (36 papers), followed by Keywords-only (21), and Abstract+Keywords (10); just eight papers matched on all three fields. The flagged set contains influential works — Voyager (2015) is the most-cited AutoVis paper — and a mix of system, design, and evaluation contributions. Examples span broad match patterns (e.g., Voyager matched in all fields) to Title-only cases like Calliope (automatic story generation), underscoring that AutoVis can appear as a central claim or a supporting angle depending on how authors frame their contributions.

information_needed.question_text: How have the absolute counts of AutoVis papers and their share of all Vis publications changed year-by-year?
transformation: filter: keep all records in the Vis dataset (no conference-level filtering unless requested)
group_by Year; compute AutoVis_Count = count(papers matching AutoVis keyword filter)
compute Total_Vis_Count = count(all papers) per Year
compute AutoVis_Share_percent = AutoVis_Count / Total_Vis_Count * 100
optional smoothing: 3-year rolling mean for AutoVis_Count and AutoVis_Share_percent (parameterizable)

information_needed.question_text: Which years show notable change points or sustained shifts in AutoVis paper counts or share that should be annotated on the time series?
information_needed.key_uncertainty: Uncertainty about how to define and detect a 'notable' change given year-to-year noise and potentially small counts (choice between raw vs smoothed series, absolute vs relative thresholds, and statistical change-point methods).
expected_outputs: Recommended detection method and parameter values (e.g., use 3-year rolling average then detect years where year-over-year percent change > 50% for at least 2 consecutive years, or apply a changepoint algorithm such as PELT with a chosen penalty).
List of candidate years (and justification) to annotate as notable change points based on the chosen method.
Recommended filters/thresholds to avoid annotating noise (e.g., ignore years where Total_Vis_Count < N or AutoVis_Count < M).

content.text: Annual counts and share reveal that AutoVis remained very rare through the 1990s and 2000s, began to appear consistently after about 2013, and then accelerated through the 2010s with a clear spike around 2015–2021. Absolute counts are small but the relative share grew markedly: the dataset peak year is 2021 with 16 AutoVis papers making up 14.7% of that year’s Vis papers, and a 3-year rolling-mean peak in share occurs around 2022 (~9.3%). Trend estimates show a positive linear slope for AutoVis share across the full period, indicating long-term increase rather than decline. That said, year-to-year volatility is high — several years after 2015 show rises and partial declines — so the pattern is best described as a recent growth trajectory with intermittent surges rather than a smooth steady expansion.

content.text: The annual counts and share visualization combines absolute AutoVis paper counts (bars) with a smoothed percent-share line (3-year rolling mean). Key takeaways: AutoVis is negligible through the 1990s and most of the 2000s, begins to appear sporadically around 2014–2015, and increases in frequency after 2015. The single-year maximum in raw count is 2021 (16 AutoVis papers; 14.7% share), and the 3-year rolling share peaks in 2022 (about 9.3%). Small absolute numbers mean a handful of papers can change annual share substantially, but the long-term slope of the share is positive (approx. 0.20 percentage points per year in the simple linear fit provided), supporting the interpretation of growth rather than decline. Notable inflection points correspond to the mid-2010s (arrival of influential recommender-style systems) and the early 2020s (a concentrated burst of mixed-initiative and deployment-related work).

report_outline.section_description: Analyze topical trends inside AutoVis using AuthorKeywords and Abstracts: keyword frequency over time, co-occurrence networks, and topic modeling (e.g., LDA or embedding + clustering). Identify canonical themes (recommendation, mixed-initiative, generation, agents, toolkits, evaluation) and how prominence shifts across years.

visualisation.specification:
{
  "$schema": "https://vega.github.io/schema/vega-lite/v5.json",
  "description": "Theme prevalence over time for AutoVis-related topics (detected by keywords in Title / Abstract / AuthorKeywords). Lines show the proportion of papers per year matching each canonical theme: recommendation, mixed-initiative, generation, agents, toolkits, evaluation.",
  "data": {"url": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/demoPlz/mini-template/main/studio/dataset.csv"},
  "transform": [
    {"calculate": "(datum.AuthorKeywords || '') + ' ' + (datum.Abstract || '') + ' ' + (datum.Title || '')", "as": "_text"},
    {"calculate": "parseInt(datum.Year, 10) || null", "as": "YearNum"},

    {"calculate": "test(/recommend|visualization recommendation|visualization recommender|automated vis|automatic vis|visualization-recommendation|visualization\\s+recommendation/i, datum._text) ? 1 : 0", "as": "recommendation"},
    {"calculate": "test(/mixed[- ]?initiative|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative/i, datum._text) ? 1 : 0", "as": "mixed_initiative"},
    {"calculate": "test(/generation|generate|vis generation|visualization generation/i, datum._text) ? 1 : 0", "as": "generation"},
    {"calculate": "test(/\\bagents?\\b|agent-based|agent system|multi-agent/i, datum._text) ? 1 : 0", "as": "agents"},
    {"calculate": "test(/toolkit|toolkits|framework|frameworks|library|libraries|\\bd3\\b|ggplot|vega-lite|vega\\b/i, datum._text) ? 1 : 0", "as": "toolkits"},
    {"calculate": "test(/evaluation|evaluate|user study|user studies|benchmark|empirical|experiment|qualitative|quantitative/i, datum._text) ? 1 : 0", "as": "evaluation"},

    {"fold": ["recommendation", "mixed_initiative", "generation", "agents", "toolkits", "evaluation"], "as": ["theme", "value"]},

    {"aggregate": [{"op": "sum", "field": "value", "as": "count"}], "groupby": ["YearNum", "theme"]},
    {"joinaggregate": [{"op": "sum", "field": "count", "as": "total_by_year"}], "groupby": ["YearNum"]},
    {"calculate": "datum.total_by_year ? datum.count / datum.total_by_year : 0", "as": "proportion"},
    {"filter": "datum.YearNum != null"}
  ],

  "width": 700,
  "height": 380,

  "params": [
    {"name": "sel_theme", "select": {"type": "point", "encodings": ["color"]}}
  ],

  "mark": {"type": "line", "point": true},

  "encoding": {
    "x": {"field": "YearNum", "type": "quantitative", "title": "Year", "axis": {"format": "d", "labelAngle": 0}},
    "y": {"field": "proportion", "type": "quantitative", "title": "Proportion of papers (per year)", "axis": {"format": ".0%"}},
    "color": {
      "field": "theme",
      "type": "nominal",
      "title": "Canonical theme",
      "scale": {
        "domain": ["recommendation", "mixed_initiative", "generation", "agents", "toolkits", "evaluation"],
        "range": ["#1f77b4", "#ff7f0e", "#2ca02c", "#d62728", "#9467bd", "#8c564b"]
      }
    },
    "opacity": {"condition": {"param": "sel_theme", "value": 1}, "value": 0.25},

    "tooltip": [
      {"field": "YearNum", "title": "Year"},
      {"field": "theme", "title": "Theme"},
      {"field": "count", "title": "Count", "type": "quantitative"},
      {"field": "total_by_year", "title": "Total papers (year)", "type": "quantitative"},
      {"field": "proportion", "title": "Proportion", "type": "quantitative", "format": ".1%"}
    ]
  }
}

content.text: Topic analysis triangulates three views — author keywords, rule-based theme detection, and unsupervised topic clustering — to chart thematic evolution. Keyword counts identify a compact vocabulary in AutoVis: explicit terms such as visualization recommendation, auto vis, and variants of mixed-initiative appear regularly, while terms linked to machine learning (reinforcement learning) and application-focused phrases emerge more recently. Rule-based theme classification (regexes applied to text) tracks canonical themes — recommendation, mixed-initiative, generation, agents, toolkits, evaluation — over time and shows that recommendation- and generation-related language grows after the mid-2010s, mixed-initiative terms persist at modest levels, and agent-related language remains relatively rare. Unsupervised topic modeling (recommended embedding+clustering pipeline) suggests 5 coarse topics where several cluster centroids emphasize evaluation, user- and task-driven work, and a separate cluster focused on rendering/volume/surface methods; the evaluation/design-related topics become dominant in the most recent years, suggesting a shift toward human-centered validation and formalized design knowledge.

The ten most frequent keywords include visualization, visual analytics, visualization recommendation, auto vis, reinforcement learning, and various mixed-initiative labels. Several patterns stand out: core terms such as visualization and visualization recommendation are persistent (appearing from early observations to 2024), visual analytics and auto vis have moderate presence but show modest decline or stabilization, and application-motivated and temporal-data keywords exhibit increasing prominence in the early 2020s. These trajectories indicate a maturing vocabulary where recommender-style work remains central while applied and data-type–specific work has become more visible recently.

content.text: The canonical-theme prevalence visualization groups AutoVis papers by simple, interpretable theme matches (recommendation, mixed-initiative, generation, agents, toolkits, evaluation) and plots each theme’s yearly proportion. Recommendation- and generation-related matches rise in the 2015–2021 window, aligning with the appearance of recommender systems and automated-generation tools; mixed-initiative labels appear steadily but never dominate; evaluation-related matches gain strength in later years, reflecting growing attention to empirical assessment and design formalization. The unsupervised topic model (embedding+clustering, k≈5) corroborates this shift: several topics are strongly evaluation- and user-focused (top words like visualization, design, user, study, evaluation), while one cluster pertains to rendering and volumetric visualization. Topic prevalence per year shows that the evaluation/design-themed topic becomes the most prevalent topic in recent years (roughly half of AutoVis papers in some recent years), signaling a thematic maturation from proof-of-concept systems toward rigorous evaluation and design knowledge.

report_outline.section_description: Identify top AutoVis papers by AminerCitationCount and CitationCount_CrossRef, plot citation trajectories, and compute latency (time from publication to peak citations). Highlight 'citation classics' and fast-rising works; contrast with non-AutoVis papers.

information_needed.question_text: Can we construct citation trajectories (year-by-year citation counts) for papers in the dataset so we can compute latency to peak and identify fast-rising works?
information_needed.key_uncertainty: The current dataset only contains cumulative citation counts (AminerCitationCount and CitationCount_CrossRef) and publication Year; it is unclear whether year-by-year citation time-series are available or can be derived from available fields or external APIs.
expected_outputs: Confirm whether any per-year citation history is present or can be constructed from InternalReferences or other fields; if not available, identify feasible external sources/APIs (CrossRef event data, Semantic Scholar, Microsoft Academic Graph archival, Google Scholar scraping) and recommended one or two to obtain yearly citation counts.

Define a practical method for computing citation trajectories and latency given likely constraints: (a) if per-year counts available, compute yearly series and smoothing (e.g., 3-year moving average), detect peak year and latency = peak_year - pub_year; (b) if only cumulative counts available, propose proxies (citations per year = cumulative / age; normalized citation rate; or collect citation snapshots from multiple sources) and thresholds for 'fast-rising' (e.g., doubling rate within first 3 years, or reaching 50% of peak within 2 years).

knowledge.facts:
### Begin of facts
No per-year citation columns were found in the dataset. Available cumulative counts: AminerCitationCount and CitationCount_CrossRef. Per-year histories cannot be constructed from these alone. Recommended external sources to obtain year-by-year citations: Semantic Scholar API (yearly citation counts), CrossRef Event Data (citation events), and (where permitted) Google Scholar snapshots. Prefer Semantic Scholar and CrossRef for structured yearly data.
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Practical methods to get citation trajectories:
(A) If per-year counts available: aggregate by year, optionally smooth with a 3-year moving average, detect peak year = year of max(smoothed counts), latency = peak_year - pub_year.
(B) If only cumulative counts: use proxies—citations_per_year = cumulative / age; identify young high-rate papers (age <=3 and high citations/year) as 'fast-rising'. Best is to fetch per-year series from Semantic Scholar or CrossRef.
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Top 5 papers by proxy citations-per-year:
D³ Data-Driven Documents | Year=2011 | Aminer=3795 | CrossRef=2178 | rate=271.1/yr | age=14
UpSet: Visualization of Intersecting Sets | Year=2014 | Aminer=1243 | CrossRef=1561 | rate=141.9/yr | age=11
Narrative Visualization: Telling Stories with Data | Year=2010 | Aminer=1408 | CrossRef=726 | rate=93.9/yr | age=15
Hierarchical Edge Bundles: Visualization of Adjacency Relations in Hierarchical Data | Year=2006 | Aminer=1395 | CrossRef=679 | rate=73.4/yr | age=19
Vega-Lite: A Grammar of Interactive Graphics | Year=2016 | Aminer=641 | CrossRef=519 | rate=71.2/yr | age=9
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Fast-rising (proxy) definition: age<=3 AND rate >= 90th percentile (10.7/yr). Matches:
Interactive and Visual Prompt Engineering for Ad-hoc Task Adaptation with Large Language Models | Year=2022 | total=0/71 | rate=23.7/yr
Dashboard Design Patterns | Year=2022 | total=0/52 | rate=17.3/yr
Design Patterns for Situated Visualization in Augmented Reality | Year=2023 | total=0/27 | rate=13.5/yr
PromptMagician: Interactive Prompt Engineering for Text-to-Image Creation | Year=2023 | total=0/26 | rate=13.0/yr
Extending the Nested Model for User-Centric XAI: A Design Study on GNN-based Drug Repurposing | Year=2022 | total=0/38 | rate=12.7/yr
Constrained Dynamic Mode Decomposition | Year=2022 | total=38/2 | rate=12.7/yr
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Automated-visualization subset: 83/3877 papers flagged. Top 3 by proxy rate:
Voyager: Exploratory Analysis via Faceted Browsing of Visualization Recommendations | Year=2015 | rate=48.7/yr | total=487/292
Formalizing Visualization Design Knowledge as Constraints: Actionable and Extensible Models in Draco | Year=2018 | rate=32.1/yr | total=225/177
A Design Space of Visualization Tasks | Year=2013 | rate=18.1/yr | total=217/144
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Recommended next steps:
1) Query Semantic Scholar API for each paper DOI to get 'citationsPerYear' timeseries (structured and free tier).
2) As fallback use CrossRef Event Data to collect citation events and aggregate by year.
3) Once timeseries obtained: smooth (3-yr MA), find peak year and compute latency = peak_year - pub_year; classify as 'fast-rising' if latency<=2 years or if cumulative citations double within first 3 years.
### End of facts

content.text: Citations identify a handful of AutoVis works that have become field-defining. Voyager (2015) is the standout AutoVis ‘classic’ with far higher citation counts than typical AutoVis papers; Draco (2018) and A Design Space of Visualization Tasks (2013) are other highly cited AutoVis-relevant works. At the corpus level a few non-AutoVis contributions (D³, UpSet, Vega-Lite) show much larger citation footprints and serve as broader field anchors. Limitations of the available data — cumulative citation totals only — prevent full reconstruction of yearly citation trajectories, so the report uses proxy rates (cumulative citations divided by age) to flag influential and fast-rising items and recommends retrieval of per-year citation series from Semantic Scholar or CrossRef for robust latency and peak-year analyses.

Automated-visualization subset: 83/3877 papers flagged. Top 3 by proxy rate:
Voyager: Exploratory Analysis via Faceted Browsing of Visualization Recommendations | Year=2015 | rate=48.7/yr | total=487/292
Formalizing Visualization Design Knowledge as Constraints: Actionable and Extensible Models in Draco | Year=2018 | rate=32.1/yr | total=225/177
A Design Space of Visualization Tasks | Year=2013 | rate=18.1/yr | total=217/144
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Recommended next steps:
1) Query Semantic Scholar API for each paper DOI to get 'citationsPerYear' timeseries (structured and free tier).
2) As fallback use CrossRef Event Data to collect citation events and aggregate by year.
3) Once timeseries obtained: smooth (3-yr MA), find peak year and compute latency = peak_year - pub_year; classify as 'fast-rising' if latency<=2 years or if cumulative citations double within first 3 years.
### End of facts
content.text: The citation-rate visualization plots a proxy metric (total Aminer citations ÷ paper age) against publication year, sizes points by total citations, and colors by whether a paper was AutoVis-flagged. Using this proxy we can flag likely ‘‘citation classics’’ and ‘‘fast-risers’’ even without full time-series: Voyager, Draco, and the Design Space paper emerge as top AutoVis items by proxy rate and total citations. The analysis also exposes a practical limitation: without year-by-year citation counts you cannot compute precise latency (time-to-peak) or smooth citation trajectories. We therefore recommend augmenting the dataset with per-year citation histories from Semantic Scholar (citationsPerYear) or CrossRef event data; once obtained, a 3-year moving average and peak-year detection will let us compute latency and classify fast-rising vs. slow-burn classics formally.

content.text: Authorship and institutional patterns reveal a classic academic structure: a long tail of one-off authors, a mid-tier of moderately productive researchers, and a smaller core of highly productive leaders who shape the field. The author-level distribution is skewed (mean ≈2.1 papers; median 1), about 2,166 authors have more than one paper, and a substantive core of established names account for a disproportionate share of output and influence. Institutionally, a small set of universities and labs produce the largest volumes and act as hubs for cross-institution collaborations; at the same time, some institutions with few papers show unexpectedly high cross-institution connectivity, indicating well-networked but low-volume contributors.

New entrants since 2020 are visible but have yet to accumulate citations, suggesting fresh activity that may influence future AutoVis directions.

content.text: The co-authorship network visualization maps collaborative structure and highlights core-periphery patterns and hubs. Several well-connected clusters center on prolific groups and individuals (for example, Huamin Qu, Yingcai Wu, Weiwei Cui and collaborators), and a small number of institutions act as major bridges across communities. Metrics show that one large institution accounts for a large share of papers and partnerships (710 papers and hundreds of partners in the provided summary), while other institutions like Hong Kong University, Zhejiang University, and several U.S. universities also appear as regional hubs. The network also contains outliers: institutions with very few papers but a high number of distinct partners, indicating wide collaboration breadth even for low-volume contributors. Overall collaboration is mixed: many single- or small-group papers exist, but cross-institution coauthorship is common among the field’s productive clusters.

If citation flows are chosen, require at least the suggested mapped links and proportion; if author spread is chosen, require filtering to authors appearing in >=2 venues.
### End of facts

content.text: AutoVis appears across the usual Vis venues but concentrated in a few places: the main Vis venue publishes the greatest number of AutoVis papers, with VAST and InfoVis also contributing substantially. Impact measures show mixed signals: mean downloads vary across venues (InfoVis papers flagged AutoVis show particularly high mean downloads), award flags exist but are rare in absolute numbers, and replicability stamps are nearly absent. Cross-venue publishing and internal-reference mapping are feasible given the dataset’s high internal-reference mapping rate, so studying diffusion across venues is practical with the available data.

### End of facts

Outliers / notable venues:
- Top 5 venues by Mean_Downloads_Xplore:
  InfoVis | MeanDownloads=2441.9 | Count=13

  SciVis | MeanDownloads=399.2 | Count=4
### End of facts
content.text: The venue-level visualization compares AutoVis paper counts with mean Downloads_Xplore and with award and replicability rates. Top venues for AutoVis papers are Vis (45 AutoVis papers, mean downloads ≈980), VAST (21, mean downloads ≈1,132), and InfoVis (13, mean downloads ≈2,442), with SciVis contributing a small number. Mean downloads do not correlate strongly with AutoVis counts (near-zero correlation in the provided summary), but award rate shows a positive association with venue counts in the summary statistics (a high correlation was reported, though this may be sensitive to small counts). GraphicsReplicabilityStamp is essentially absent for AutoVis papers in these venues, which points to a major reproducibility gap despite solid download performance for some venues.

### End of facts
content.text: The internal-references / cross-venue diagnostics show that nearly all internal references can be resolved to DOIs within the dataset: of ~24,866 exploded internal references, about 24,602 mapped to DOIs present in the corpus (≈98.9% mapping). This high mapping rate plus the observation that ~1,050 deduped authors publish in two or more distinct venues implies that tracing cross-venue citation flows and author diffusion is practical. Venue-spread among authors is modest on average (mean ≈1.19 venues per author; median 1) but a meaningful minority publish across venues, offering a basis to study how AutoVis ideas travel between subcommunities.

report_outline.section_description: Summarize takeaways: what happened to AutoVis research, the field’s maturity, gaps (evaluation, reproducibility, deployment), and actionable recommendations for researchers (promising directions and methodological best practices).

content.text: AutoVis is small in absolute size but shows a clear growth signal: it has moved from sporadic system-building and rendering work to a more diverse portfolio that includes recommendation systems, mixed-initiative interfaces, model-based design tools, and increased attention to empirical evaluation. Key successes (Voyager, Draco) demonstrate the field’s potential to influence mainstream Vis practice, yet important gaps remain. Reproducibility indicators (GraphicsReplicabilityStamp) are nearly absent, award mentions are sparse, and citation-time-series are not present in the dataset — making it hard to measure long-term impact and latency to influence. Recommended actions for researchers: (1) prioritize reproducibility by releasing code, data, and replicability artifacts and by using or advocating for replicability stamps; (2) publish per-paper persistent identifiers and fetch per-year citation histories (Semantic Scholar / CrossRef) to enable robust impact analyses; (3) combine computational advances (e.g., reinforcement learning, embedding-driven generation) with human-centered evaluation to close the loop between algorithmic promise and usability; (4) assemble benchmark tasks, datasets, and evaluation protocols to compare AutoVis approaches systematically; and (5) continue cross-venue and cross-discipline collaborations to ensure ideas move from prototypical systems to broadly used toolkits and deployed applications. Collectively, these steps will help AutoVis mature from a promising niche into a reproducible, impactful subfield of visualization.
